questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a throbbing left-sided headache that started 3 hours ago. Two hours ago, she took ibuprofen with no relief. She has been vomiting every 20 minutes since the start of the headache. She reports that she could not see very well for a few minutes this morning. A similar episode occurred 2 months ago. She is otherwise healthy and has recently started taking an oral contraceptive. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities except mild sensitivity to light. Visual acuity is 20/20. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dihydroergotamine and sumatriptan are both indicated as abortive drugs for patients who have failed NSAID monotherapy. However, ergotamine and triptans should never be combined because they both have vasoconstrictive effects, which can lead to complications such as stroke or myocardial infarction.

B) INCORRECT:

Triptans (e.g., zolmitriptan) are a first-line abortive therapy for migraines, and tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline) are used for migraine prophylaxis. While zolmitriptan is appropriate for this patient, migraine prophylaxis is usually indicated for those with > 2 attacks/month and/or severe attacks, or when abortive medications fail to relieve symptoms. This patient has had two sporadic attacks and has not exhausted abortive therapy options, so prophylactic therapy is not currently indicated.

C) CORRECT:

Parenteral antidopaminergic antiemetics such as metoclopramide or prochlorperazine are first-line agents for monotherapy for acute migraine attacks, especially if the migraine is associated with vomiting. These antiemetics effects have a direct abortive effect on migraine symptoms regardless of GI symptoms or ability to tolerate oral medication. In addition, they facilitate absorption of oral medications (e.g., NSAIDs). Oral antiemetics, on the other hand, are not as effective as monotherapy for acute migraine attacks. To prevent extrapyramidal symptoms (e.g., akathisia), which are a potential side effect of these agents, intravenous diphenhydramine can be added to the treatment.

Because oral contraceptives (OCPs) are a potential trigger of migraine headaches, discontinuation should be discussed with this patient after successful treatment of her acute migraine attack. In addition, because of an increased risk of stroke, the use of combined OCPs is contraindicated in patients with migraines with aura and patients with migraines without aura but with other risk factors for stroke.

D) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers (e.g., propanolol) are the first-line option for migraine prophylaxis, which is indicated for those with > 2 attacks/month and/or severe attacks, or when abortive medications fail to relieve symptoms. This patient has had two sporadic attacks and has not exhausted abortive therapy options, so prophylactic therapy is not currently indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Ergotamine is used as an abortive drug for patients with moderate to severe migraine attacks and can be combined with NSAIDs (e.g., ketorolac) for greater efficacy. This patient's migraines are associated with repeated vomiting, which would not be treated adequately with this combination of oral drugs.
questions.hint: A unilateral throbbing headache with vomiting and transient visual disturbances is highly suggestive of a diagnosis of migraine with aura.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a severe, throbbing headache for 1 hour. The headache is located in the right frontotemporal region. It is her fifth such headache in the past 2 months. Her mother says that all the previous episodes started after soccer practice, following which the child would lock herself in her room, close the curtains, and sleep for a few hours. After waking up, the headache is either diminished or has stopped entirely. One month ago, the child was diagnosed with myopic vision and has been wearing glasses since. Her 4-year-old brother had herpetic gingivostomatitis 2 months ago. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Funduscopic examination is inconclusive because the child is uncooperative. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neuro-optometric assessment would be indicated for suspected refraction error, which may present with headache. Although this patient has myopia, she was recently evaluated and has been wearing corrective lenses; refractive error should not be contributing to her symptoms. In addition, the unilateral, recurrent, throbbing character of her headache suggests migraine, rather than ocular headache. Ocular headaches have a broad clinical presentation, but they tend to occur later in the day, especially after long periods of eye strain (e.g., after reading a book or working on a computer for hours).
Image Description:

Deviations in eye anatomy that affect refractory media (e.g., axial length of the eye, cornea curvature) can result in refractive errors.

Emmetropia: The axial length of the eye and refractive power are balanced, resulting in a focal point on the retina.

Myopia: An increased axial length of the eye or increased refractive power results in a focal point anterior to the retina. Near objects can be seen clearly but distant objects are blurred. This can be corrected using a concave (diverging) lens.

Hyperopia: A decreased axial length of the eye or decreased refractive power results in a focal point posterior to the retina. Distant objects and even near objects may be seen clearly depending on the ability of the lens to accommodate (generally, the younger the individual, the greater the ability to accommodate) and the degree of hyperopia. Hyperopia can be corrected using a convex (converging) lens.

B) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture (LP) is indicated to diagnose intracranial hypertension, infection (e.g., meningitis), or hemorrhage, all of which may manifest with headache. Intracranial infection or hemorrhage manifests as acute, progressive headache, while headache associated with idiopathic intracranial hypertension is usually positional (e.g., exacerbated by leaning forward or lying down). This patient's chronic, episodic symptoms that are relieved by sleep suggest migraine headaches, for which LP is not diagnostic.

C) CORRECT:

NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) or acetaminophen are the first-line abortive treatment for children with migraine. These therapies are generally safe and effective for children, and have minimal side effects. Abortive therapy should be administered immediately, as it is most effective when taken at the onset of migraine. If the first agent (e.g., ibuprofen) fails to relieve symptoms, the other agent (e.g., acetaminophen) may also be given. A headache calendar should also be recommended to elucidate environmental triggers of headache (e.g., strenuous exercise, stress, certain food).

D) INCORRECT:

Dihydroergotamine is a second-line abortive medication for moderate to severe migraine because it has a higher risk of adverse effects compared to other abortive medications. Other medications should be tried in this patient before dihydroergotamine is indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Neuroimaging (e.g., MRI of the brain) is indicated in children with headaches if there is suspicion for an intracranial lesion (e.g., craniopharyngioma). Features that should raise concern for intracranial pathologies include age < 6 years; history of seizure; recent head trauma; chronic progressive headache; change in character, severity, or frequency of headaches; and abnormal neurological examination findings. Children with a clinical history consistent with typical migraine headaches whose neurological examination is normal do not require brain imaging.

F) INCORRECT:

Amitriptyline is indicated for migraine prophylaxis, which is used if all abortive medications have failed, or if migraines are very frequent or prolonged. Before initiating prophylaxis in this patient, lifestyle modifications and abortive medication should be attempted.

G) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir should be initiated as soon as a herpetic intracranial infection (e.g., HSV encephalitis) is suspected. While this patient's sibling recently had a herpetic infection, patients with HSV encephalitis typically present with a combination of headache, fever, altered mental status, and focal neurological deficits. This patient's chronic, unilateral, episodic headaches without associated neurological abnormalities make herpetic infection unlikely.
questions.hint: This child presents with a history of recurrent, debilitating, unilateral headache episodes, which seem to be provoked by physical activity and spontaneously resolve with sleep. These headaches appear to be associated with increased sensitivity to light (e.g., during funduscopy). The absence of fever, loss of consciousness, neurological deficits, or neck stiffness make migraine the most likely diagnosis in this patient.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of pain in the left cheek. The pain occurs every few hours, lasts 30–60 seconds, and is aggravated by chewing and brushing her teeth. She has a history of pain with a vesicular rash in the right axillary area 1 year ago. She had an upper respiratory infection 2 weeks ago. Family history is unremarkable. Her vital signs are within normal limits and physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cluster headaches usually manifest as attacks of intense unilateral facial pain, occurring ∼ 8 times per day and lasting ∼ 15 minutes, in contrast to this patient's episodic pain that lasts 30–60 seconds. The pain is also usually periorbital or temporal rather than in the cheeks. In addition, autonomic symptoms, such as conjunctival injection, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, and nasal congestion, are often seen in association with cluster headaches.

B) INCORRECT:

Paroxysmal hemicrania manifests as recurring unilateral periorbital headaches that occur > 5 times per day and last for 2–45 minutes, in contrast to this patient's episodic cheek pain that lasts 30–60 seconds. In addition, autonomic symptoms, such as conjunctival injection, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, and nasal congestion, are often seen in association with paroxysmal hemicrania.

C) CORRECT:

Trigeminal neuralgia (TN) is a chronic pain syndrome characterized by transient (< 1 minute), recurrent, severe shooting, stabbing, and/or paroxysmal pain that can occur up to 100 times per day in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve. TN most commonly manifests with pain shooting from the mouth to the angle of the jaw. Episodes can be triggered by a variety of stimuli, such as brushing teeth, chewing, cold, and touch. TN is a progressive disease (i.e., attacks become more frequent over time) and can cause psychological distress, leading to depression and even suicidal ideation.

TN is typically caused by neurovascular compression, most often by an aberrant loop of a neighboring artery (usually the superior cerebellar artery). Secondary TN is often associated with multiple sclerosis, particularly in cases in which the disease manifests bilaterally in young women.
Image Description:

Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by attacks of facial pain in the area of one or more branches of the trigeminal nerve. Classical trigeminal neuralgia is caused by neurovascular compression, most often by an aberrant loop of a neighboring artery (usually the superior cerebellar artery). The pain is typically very severe in intensity, has a sharp, stabbing quality, and lasts several seconds. Attacks can occur without provocation but are sometimes triggered by stimuli such as brushing teeth.

D) INCORRECT:

Postherpetic neuralgia manifests with recurrent pain, burning, and/or loss of sensation that affects the same region as a prior shingles flare. This patient has pain in the left cheek, in contrast to the right axilla affected a year ago.

E) INCORRECT:

Sinus headaches are caused by bacterial infection of the maxillary sinuses, usually following a viral upper respiratory infection. Bacterial sinusitis manifests as constant infraorbital pain and tenderness to palpation over the maxillary sinuses that is aggravated by leaning forward, which is not seen in this patient. Patients also usually manifest with fever, malaise, and/or purulent nasal discharge.

F) INCORRECT:

Temporal arteritis can manifest with constant pain over the temples that is aggravated by chewing, in contrast to this patient's episodic cheek pain that lasts 30–60 seconds. Pain associated with temporal arteritis usually manifests as new-onset, pulse-synchronous, dull throbbing headache, with associated jaw claudication. Moreover, temporal arteritis is rarely observed in patients < 50 years of age, and patients often also have scalp tenderness, weight loss, new-onset vision loss, and/or a history of amaurosis fugax.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms are most likely unrelated to her prior rash and upper respiratory infection. The first-line therapy for her condition is carbamazepine.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of an excruciating headache that started 30 minutes ago. The pain is located around the right eye and it awoke him from sleep. Over the past two weeks, he has had similar headaches around the same time of the day, and he reports pacing around restlessly during these episodes. Physical examination shows conjunctival injection and tearing of the right eye. In addition to supplemental oxygen therapy, administration of which of the following drugs is most likely to provide acute relief in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Indomethacin is highly effective in preventing attacks of paroxysmal hemicrania (PH), a rare form of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia, but not very effective as an abortive therapy in acute cases. While PH may present very similarly, the attacks are usually more frequent (≥ 5 per day) and often shorter. In cluster headache, NSAIDs like indomethacin are generally not recommended because their onset of action is too slow.

B) CORRECT:

Triptans like sumatriptan are the first-line pharmacological treatment for acute attacks of cluster headache. They abort the headache and provide resolution of the conjunctival injection associated with these attacks. The exact mechanism is unclear, but it is thought to involve the vasoconstriction of cranial blood vessels in response to stimulation of 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT) receptors. Inhalation of 100% oxygen is also effective in terminating acute episodes of cluster headache and has a rapid onset of action.

Triptans are also the treatment of choice for severe migraine attacks.

C) INCORRECT:

NSAIDs like ibuprofen can be used for pain relief in, e.g. mild to moderate migraine attacks or acute tension-type headaches (TTH). While the pain associated with TTH is usually holocephalic or bifrontal, and cranial autonomic symptoms, as seen in this patient, do not occur; migraine is characterized by episodes of typically unilateral headache lasting 4–72 hours accompanied or preceded by nausea, phono- and photophobia, and/or aura, which are absent in this patient. Furthermore, while patients with migraine tend to rest motionlessly in a quiet, dark room, this patient prefers to pace around during the episodes of pain.

D) INCORRECT:

Carbamazepine is the drug of choice for the treatment of trigeminal neuralgia. While trigeminal neuralgia can present with unilateral facial pain that occurs in repetitive attacks, unlike in this patient, these attacks usually only last a few seconds and are characterized by shooting or stabbing pain (like an electric shock) from mouth to the angle of the jaw on the affected side. Frontal headache, conjunctival injection, rhinorrhea, and lacrimation are not features of trigeminal neuralgia.
Image Description:

Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by attacks of facial pain in the area of one or more branches of the trigeminal nerve. Classical trigeminal neuralgia is caused by neurovascular compression, most often by an aberrant loop of a neighboring artery (usually the superior cerebellar artery). The pain is typically very severe in intensity, has a sharp, stabbing quality, and lasts several seconds. Attacks can occur without provocation but are sometimes triggered by stimuli such as brushing teeth.

E) INCORRECT:

Amitriptyline is used to prevent chronic tension-type headaches and migraine attacks. Amitriptyline is not used, however, to acutely treat any type of headache.

F) INCORRECT:

High-dose steroid therapy is the treatment of choice for giant cell arteritis (GCA), which can present with severe unilateral headache, as seen in this patient. However, autonomic symptoms do not occur, and symptoms such as jaw claudication and scalp tenderness, which are not seen in this patient, are usually present. More importantly, GCA usually occurs in elderly individuals (peak incidence: 70–79 years) and is rare in patients younger than 50.

Prednisone can be used as a preventive treatment for cluster headache; however, this patient with an acute presentation needs an abortive therapy.
Image Description:

Certain pain characteristics and associated symptoms can help in the diagnosis of a secondary headache:

– Temporal arteritis: unilateral headache, jaw claudication, tenderness of scalp or temporal artery, constitutional symptoms, visual changes
– Hypertensive crisis: diffuse, often bifrontal, headache (Headache in the setting of hypertensive crisis can be an isolated finding but may also be a manifestation of hypertensive encephalopathy, which constitutes a hypertensive emergency)
– Sinusitis: Facial pain or pressure in the sinus cavity region, purulent rhinorrhea, flu-like symptoms
– Medication overuse headache: diffuse headache that can change in type and location within an episode and has developed or worsened with pain medication overuse

G) INCORRECT:

Oxycodone is an orally administered opiate analgesic that is used to treat chronic and/or severe pain that cannot be managed with NSAIDs. Opiate analgesics should not, however, be used in the management of primary headache disorders because of the risk of opiate dependence.
questions.hint: This young man has recurrent attacks of severe unilateral headache that are associated with ipsilateral cranial autonomic symptoms (conjunctival injection, lacrimation), which is indicative of cluster headache.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old female nurse who has had episodic, sickening headaches since high school reports that her headaches have become more frequent in recent years. She currently suffers, up to 3 times per week, from severe, unilateral throbbing head pressure that can last all day and that prompts her to lie down in a dark room. She has become increasingly disabled by her headaches.
She takes two tablets of an over-the-counter combination analgesic (acetaminophen-aspirin-caffeine) as needed, but it is not always effective. She uses no other medications. She is a nonsmoker, is currently not sexually active, and has no other neurologic symptoms or systemic complaints.
She has normal vital signs and a BMI of 32. Funduscopic, visual acuity, neurologic, and musculoskeletal examinations are all normal.
In addition to lifestyle modification, which one of the following preventive treatments is the most appropriate first-line therapy for this patient?

choices.text: A trial of 100% oxygen therapy at home

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oxygen therapy is appropriate only for cluster headaches, which are typically unilateral, are often retro-orbital and temporal, and nearly always have ipsilateral autonomic signs, such as conjunctival injection, lacrimation, nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, facial sweating, miosis, ptosis, or eyelid edema.

B) INCORRECT:

Although several nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) have been shown to be potentially effective in migraine prevention, they are generally not preferred as first-line daily preventive therapy because they can contribute to medication overuse headache (rebound headache) when used frequently. An evidence-based guideline from the American Academy of Neurology lists the NSAIDs naproxen, ibuprofen, ketoprofen, and fenoprofen — but not indomethacin — as “probably effective” for migraine prevention.

C) CORRECT:

Migraine headaches can occur with or without aura, but the latter is more common. Migraine without aura is defined as a history of five or more episodes that

• Last 4 to 72 hours each
• Have at least two of the following features: unilateral location, pulsating quality, moderate to severe pain, and exacerbation with routine physical activities
• Are accompanied by at least one of the following symptoms: nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or phonophobia
• Cannot be attributed to another disorder

Factors that should prompt consideration of preventive therapy include the occurrence of >2 migraines per month, with disability lasting ≥3 days per month; failure of, contraindication for, or adverse events from acute treatments; use of abortive medication more than twice per week; and uncommon migraine conditions (e.g., hemiplegic migraine, migraine with prolonged aura, migrainous infarction).

First-line therapies for migraine prophylaxis in adults include propranolol, metoprolol, timolol, amitriptyline, sodium valproate, and topiramate. Because topiramate can facilitate weight loss, it is often a preferred choice for managing patients with obesity and frequent migraine. Of note, many of these medications, particularly sodium valproate and topiramate, should be used with caution in women of reproductive age, and appropriate contraceptive methods should be considered.

Key learning point: High-frequency and disabling episodic migraine should be treated with daily preventive medication such as a beta-blocker, amitriptyline, sodium valproate, or topiramate.

D) INCORRECT:

Acetazolamide can treat idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) but is not effective in the treatment of migraine. IIH is rare (prevalence of about 1 in 5000 among young women with obesity) and would be suggested by the presence of papilledema on fundoscopy. Before initiation of treatment for this condition, the diagnosis should be established by measuring the lumbar-puncture opening pressure.

E) INCORRECT:

Rizatriptan, an acute-migraine medication, is not appropriate for daily or preventive use.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman seeks treatment for severe, episodic headaches that have caused her to miss work and family activities for many years. Although she occasionally experiences one or two episodes monthly for several months, her more typical pattern is headache-free periods of 3 to 4 months. The headaches can be right-sided, left-sided, or both; reach 7 out of 10 in intensity; and make her want to lie down in a dark, quiet place. Within minutes after the onset of pain, she vomits, sometimes repeatedly. Roughly one-third of the episodes are preceded by shimmering lights and progressive blind spots in her vision that spontaneously resolve after 30 minutes. An over-the-counter migraine medication (containing acetaminophen 250 mg, aspirin 250 mg, and caffeine 65 mg) is not helpful. Her sister, who has similar headaches, urged her to seek medical care.
The patient jogs five miles several times per week. Her father had a myocardial infarction at age 65.
During her most recent headache, the patient’s blood pressure was noted to be 138/85 mm Hg at her occupational health office. Her current blood pressure is 118/75 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 62 beats per minute. General physical and neurological examinations are normal.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has approved propranolol and topiramate for migraine prevention; however, if headache frequency is low, daily preventive therapy may not be warranted.

B) INCORRECT:

Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, including ibuprofen, have been shown to be efficacious as acute migraine abortives; however, orally administered medications are not preferable for a patient with early vomiting.

C) INCORRECT:

Given the vomiting at the onset of her symptoms, a non-orally delivered triptan is preferable to an oral triptan.

D) CORRECT:

For a young woman with migraine who has severe symptoms, including vomiting at onset, and who does not reliably respond to simple or combination analgesics, a non-orally delivered triptan is the most appropriate first-line treatment.

Visual aura, family history of coronary artery disease, and mild blood pressure elevations during pain are not contraindications to triptan use. Contraindications include known or strongly suspected vascular disease (including ischemic heart disease), significant renal or hepatic disease, poorly controlled hypertension, and hemiplegia or brainstem symptoms during aura. Although this patient's family history of ischemic heart disease is not a contraindication to triptan use, it should prompt the clinician to carefully question the patient about possible symptoms of ischemic heart disease before prescribing the medication.

Subcutaneous sumatriptan has the highest therapeutic gain over placebo of any available treatment, and onset of relief is rapid. It is preferable to an oral triptan in this patient, given the vomiting at the onset of her symptoms.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for a patient with severe, episodic, low-frequency migraine that is characterized by vomiting at onset and is not responsive to combination analgesics is subcutaneous sumatriptan.

E) INCORRECT:

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has approved propranolol and topiramate for migraine prevention; however, if headache frequency is low, daily preventive therapy may not be warranted.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man is evaluated for headaches that occur multiple times per week and frequently reach a maximum pain intensity of 8 out of 10. The headaches are usually unilateral but can occur on either side, and the patient has to stay in a dark room when they are severe.
He cannot identify any dietary triggers for the headaches. He is a graduate student with a heavy course load and an erratic schedule, frequently skipping meals and studying late into the night. He drinks caffeine daily with no effect on the headaches.
Daily prophylactic management of his headaches has failed because of poor adherence. His history is notable for one episode of hematemesis that occurred during a headache episode in which he took large doses of ibuprofen.
Which one of the following options is the most appropriate first step for managing this patient’s headaches?

choices.text: Counseling regarding improved lifestyle measures, including regular meal and sleep times
Oral acetaminophen every 4 hours around the clock
Daily use of ibuprofen with a concomitant histamine-2-receptor blocker to prevent headaches

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s history is consistent with migraine, which is defined by headaches that last 4 to 72 hours each, involve nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or phonophobia as symptoms, and have at least two of the following features: unilateral location, pulsating quality, moderate to severe intensity, and exacerbation with routine physical activity. Nonpharmacologic options should be the first step in migraine management if possible. Erratic sleep and meal schedules are common exacerbating factors for migraine, as are dehydration, emotional stress, hormonal changes, and alcohol use. Adopting a regular schedule for meals, sleep, and exercise may help prevent migraines. If these measures do not work, consideration can be given to other nonpharmacologic methods (such as biofeedback or acupuncture) or to pharmacologic methods (such as triptans, daily prophylactic medications, or botulinum toxin injections). This patient’s headaches are frequent enough to warrant prophylactic therapy, but his nonadherence makes this option less likely to succeed, and he has had adverse events with ibuprofen. Therefore, counseling about lifestyle measures is the most appropriate next step.

Key learning point: The first step in effective nonpharmacologic management of migraine is lifestyle measures, including regular meals, regular sleep, hydration, and regular exercise.

B) INCORRECT:

Acetaminophen is unlikely to provide significant pain relief for a patient experiencing multiple headaches per week. In addition, long-term acetaminophen use carries a risk of hepatotoxicity and may induce medication-overuse headaches.

C) INCORRECT:

Medical marijuana is not an approved modality for treatment of headaches.

D) INCORRECT:

Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are associated with an increased risk for gastric ulcers and bleeding, and this patient is at high risk, given that he has already had one episode of gastric ulcer in the setting of high-dose NSAID use. Data suggest that concomitant use of either a proton pump inhibitor or a histamine-2-receptor antagonist can prevent NSAID-induced gastric injury. However, this pharmacologic approach is not ideal for a patient with a history of medication nonadherence. Furthermore, the use of NSAIDs for more than 2 to 3 days per week can result in medication-overuse headaches.

E) INCORRECT:

Opioids have poor efficacy for chronic headache, carry significant risks for misuse or dependence, and can also induce medication-overuse headache.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman reports that she has had recurrent headaches for the past 4 months. The headaches initially occurred once or twice per week and would last about a day, but the frequency has increased, and they now occur on most days of the week. The pain is dull and aching and is centered over the top and back of her head; sometimes it awakens her in the middle of the night. She reports no photophobia but frequently becomes nauseated with the headaches. She vomited twice last week when getting out of bed. She has had no vision changes and no periods of confusion.
She had migraine headaches when she was younger but reports that they were slightly different in quality and location than her current headaches. She has no other medical problems and takes no medications other than as-needed acetaminophen, which has not been helping.
On physical examination, she has a blood pressure of 114/72 mm Hg, a heart rate of 81 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute while she breathes ambient air, and a temperature of 37.8°C. She is alert and has normal mental status.
A detailed neurologic examination, including funduscopic examination, is normal except for mild dysmetria of the right arm.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Observe with close follow-up and a headache diary

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Head CT would be warranted if there were clinical concern for acute, increased intracranial pressure or hemorrhage, but it is not the ideal imaging test for posterior fossa structures and would expose this patient to unnecessary radiation.

B) INCORRECT:

Observation alone is not sufficient in a patient with red-flag symptoms.

C) CORRECT:

Routine neuroimaging is not warranted for most cases of recurrent headache; neuroimaging is typically reserved for patients with recurrent headaches who have new focal neurologic symptoms or physical exam findings, a change in characteristics, pattern, or severity of headaches, or seizures. It may also be reasonable to obtain neuroimaging in patients who present with onset of headaches after age 50. This patient has progressively worsening headaches, with some pain at night and at least two episodes of early-morning emesis. Furthermore, the pain is occipital, and she has dysmetria on examination. Together, these findings may suggest a lesion occupying the posterior fossa space, which merits MRI evaluation.

Key learning point: Recurrent headaches that are associated with pain during sleep or with morning emesis — or that are worsening progressively — merit evaluation with brain MRI.

D) INCORRECT:

Pharmacologic management (e.g., with topiramate) is not appropriate as a first step for a patient with red-flag symptoms. Topiramate is a reasonable treatment for migraine prophylaxis. However, this patient’s current symptoms and neurologic examination are concerning for a space-occupying lesion and warrant further examination.

E) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic lumbar puncture is not indicated in the evaluation of recurrent headache. Given the concern for a space-occupying lesion in this patient, neuroimaging is the most appropriate next step in evaluation.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl reports that she has had recurrent headaches for the past 4 months. The headaches initially occurred once or twice per week and would last about a day, but the frequency has increased, and they now occur on most days of the week. The pain is dull and aching and is centered over the top and back of her head; sometimes it awakens her in the middle in the night. She reports no photophobia but frequently becomes nauseated with the headaches. She vomited twice last week when getting out of bed. She has had no vision changes and no periods of confusion.
She had migraine headaches when she was younger but reports that they were slightly different in quality and location than her current headaches. She has no other medical problems and takes no medications other than as-needed acetaminophen, which has not been helping. She is doing well in school and has no recent family stressors.
On physical examination, she has a blood pressure of 114/72 mm Hg, a heart rate of 81 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute while she breathes ambient air, and a temperature of 37.8°C. She is alert and has normal mental status.
A detailed neurologic examination, including funduscopic examination, is normal except for mild dysmetria of the right arm.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Observe with close follow-up and a headache diary

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Observation alone is not sufficient in a patient with red-flag symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic lumbar puncture is not indicated in the evaluation of recurrent headache. Given the concern for a space-occupying lesion in this patient, neuroimaging is the most appropriate next step in evaluation.

C) INCORRECT:

Head CT would be warranted if there were clinical concern for acute, increased intracranial pressure or hemorrhage, but it is not the ideal imaging test for posterior fossa structures and would expose this patient to unnecessary radiation.

D) CORRECT:

Routine neuroimaging is not warranted for most cases of recurrent headache. According to practice parameters set forth by the American Academy of Neurology and agreed upon by the American Academy of Pediatrics, neuroimaging should be reserved for patients with recurrent headache who have focal neurologic findings, worsening or progressive headaches, or seizures.

This patient has progressively worsening headaches, with some pain at night and at least two episodes of early-morning emesis. Furthermore, the pain is occipital, and she has dysmetria on examination. Together, these findings may suggest a lesion occupying the posterior fossa space, which merits MRI evaluation.

Key learning point: Recurrent headaches that are associated with pain during sleep or with morning emesis — or that are worsening progressively — merit evaluation with brain MRI.

E) INCORRECT:

Pharmacologic management (e.g., with topiramate) is not appropriate as a first step for a patient with red-flag symptoms. Topiramate is approved for migraine prophylaxis in children aged 12 to 17. Although this patient has a history of migraine headaches, her current symptoms and neurologic examination are concerning for a space-occupying lesion and warrant further examination.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman reports that she has had recurrent headaches for the past 4 months. The headaches initially occurred once or twice per week, but the frequency has increased, and they now occur on most days of the week. The pain is dull and centered over the back of her head; sometimes it awakens her in the middle of the night. She vomited twice last week when getting out of bed. She takes no medications other than as-needed acetaminophen, which has not been helping. Neurologic examination shows dysmetria of the right arm. Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Observe with close follow-up and a headache diary

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Head CT would be warranted if there were clinical concern for acute, increased intracranial pressure or hemorrhage, but it is not the ideal imaging test for posterior fossa structures and would expose this patient to unnecessary radiation.

B) INCORRECT:

Observation alone is not sufficient in a patient with red-flag symptoms.

C) CORRECT:

Routine neuroimaging is not warranted for most cases of recurrent headache; neuroimaging is typically reserved for patients with recurrent headaches who have new focal neurologic symptoms or physical exam findings, a change in characteristics, pattern, or severity of headaches, or seizures. It may also be reasonable to obtain neuroimaging in patients who present with onset of headaches after age 50. This patient's findings may suggest a lesion occupying the posterior fossa space, which merits MRI evaluation.

Key learning point: Recurrent headaches that are associated with pain during sleep or with morning emesis — or that are worsening progressively — merit evaluation with brain MRI.

D) INCORRECT:

Pharmacologic management (e.g., with topiramate) is not appropriate as a first step for a patient with red-flag symptoms. Topiramate is a reasonable treatment for migraine prophylaxis. However, this patient’s current symptoms and neurologic examination are concerning for a space-occupying lesion and warrant further examination.

E) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic lumbar puncture is not indicated in the evaluation of recurrent headache. Given the concern for a space-occupying lesion in this patient, neuroimaging is the most appropriate next step in evaluation.
questions.hint: This patient has progressively worsening occipital headaches, pain at night, episodes of early-morning emesis, and dysmetria on examination. Together, these findings may suggest a space-occupying lesion of the posterior fossa.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with a 3-day history of pain in her left cheek. The pain occurs every few hours, lasts 30–60 seconds, and is aggravated by chewing and brushing her teeth. She reports a previous episode of pain with a vesicular rash in the right axillary area 1 year ago. She had an upper respiratory infection 2 weeks ago. Family history is unremarkable. Vital signs are normal and physical examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Trigeminal neuralgia (TN) is a chronic pain syndrome characterized by transient (< 1 minute), recurrent, severe shooting, stabbing, and/or paroxysmal pain that can occur up to 100 times per day in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve. TN most commonly manifests with pain shooting from the mouth to the angle of the jaw. Episodes can be triggered by a variety of stimuli, such as brushing teeth, chewing, cold, and touch. TN is a progressive disease (i.e., attacks become more frequent over time) and can cause psychological distress, leading to depression and even suicidal ideation.

TN is typically caused by neurovascular compression, most often by an aberrant loop of a neighboring artery (usually the superior cerebellar artery). Secondary TN is often associated with multiple sclerosis, particularly in cases in which the disease manifests bilaterally in young women.

Key learning point: Trigeminal neuralgia presents as recurrent, brief, severe, unilateral facial pain triggered by activities like chewing or brushing teeth, most often due to neurovascular compression of the trigeminal nerve.
Image Description:

Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by attacks of facial pain in the area of one or more branches of the trigeminal nerve. Classical trigeminal neuralgia is caused by neurovascular compression, most often by an aberrant loop of a neighboring artery (usually the superior cerebellar artery). The pain is typically very severe in intensity, has a sharp, stabbing quality, and lasts several seconds. Attacks can occur without provocation but are sometimes triggered by stimuli such as brushing teeth.

B) INCORRECT:

Sinus headaches are caused by bacterial infection of the maxillary sinuses, usually following a viral upper respiratory infection. Bacterial sinusitis manifests as constant infraorbital pain and tenderness to palpation over the maxillary sinuses that is aggravated by leaning forward, which is not seen in this patient. Patients also usually manifest with fever, malaise, and/or purulent nasal discharge.

C) INCORRECT:

Temporal arteritis can manifest with constant pain over the temples that is aggravated by chewing, in contrast to this patient's episodic cheek pain that lasts 30–60 seconds. Pain associated with temporal arteritis usually manifests as new-onset, pulse-synchronous, dull throbbing headache, with associated jaw claudication. Moreover, temporal arteritis is rarely observed in patients < 50 years of age, and patients often also have scalp tenderness, weight loss, new-onset vision loss, and/or a history of amaurosis fugax.

D) INCORRECT:

Cluster headaches usually manifest as attacks of intense unilateral facial pain, occurring ∼ 8 times per day and lasting ∼ 15 minutes, in contrast to this patient's episodic pain that lasts 30–60 seconds. The pain is also usually periorbital or temporal rather than in the cheeks. In addition, autonomic symptoms, such as conjunctival injection, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, and nasal congestion, are often seen in association with cluster headaches.

E) INCORRECT:

Postherpetic neuralgia manifests with recurrent pain, burning, and/or loss of sensation that affects the same region as a prior shingles flare. This patient has pain in the left cheek, in contrast to the right axilla affected a year ago.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms are most likely unrelated to her prior rash and upper respiratory infection. The first-line therapy for her condition is carbamazepine.

questions.text: You are seeing a 23-year-old woman who reports a 4-month history of recurrent headaches. The headaches began once or twice per week but have increased in frequency and now occur on most days. The pain is described as dull and located at the back of her head, and sometimes it awakens her at night. She vomited twice last week when getting out of bed. She does not take any medications except for as-needed acetaminophen, which has not provided relief. On neurologic examination, she has dysmetria of the right arm. Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Observe with close follow-up and a headache diary.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Routine neuroimaging is not warranted for most cases of recurrent headache; neuroimaging is typically reserved for patients with recurrent headaches who have new focal neurologic symptoms or physical exam findings, a change in characteristics, pattern, or severity of headaches, or seizures. It may also be reasonable to obtain neuroimaging in patients who present with onset of headaches after age 50. This patient's findings may suggest a lesion occupying the posterior fossa space, which merits MRI evaluation.

Key learning point: Recurrent headaches that are associated with pain during sleep or with morning emesis — or that are worsening progressively — merit evaluation with brain MRI.

B) INCORRECT:

Pharmacologic management (e.g., with topiramate) is not appropriate as a first step for a patient with red-flag symptoms. Topiramate is a reasonable treatment for migraine prophylaxis. However, this patient’s current symptoms and neurologic examination are concerning for a space-occupying lesion and warrant further examination.

C) INCORRECT:

Observation alone is not sufficient in a patient with red-flag symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic lumbar puncture is not indicated in the evaluation of recurrent headache. Given the concern for a space-occupying lesion in this patient, neuroimaging is the most appropriate next step in evaluation.

E) INCORRECT:

Head CT would be warranted if there were clinical concern for acute, increased intracranial pressure or hemorrhage, but it is not the ideal imaging test for posterior fossa structures and would expose this patient to unnecessary radiation.
questions.hint: This patient has progressively worsening occipital headaches, pain at night, episodes of early-morning emesis, and dysmetria on examination. Together, these findings may suggest a space-occupying lesion of the posterior fossa.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents with sudden-onset severe headache that began 3 hours ago during a weight lifting class. She reports one episode of similar headache two weeks ago. Vital signs are BP, 145/88; P, 92; T, 36.9°C (98.4°F). Neurological examination shows neck stiffness. Head CT without contrast performed 4 hours after symptom onset is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge with return precautions and neurology follow-up
CT angiography of the head and neck

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Discharge would be inappropriate given the high clinical suspicion for subarachnoid hemorrhage based on sudden onset severe headache during exertion. Given the abnormal neurological findings, further diagnostic evaluation is required despite the negative initial CT.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – CT angiography of the head and neck is an appropriate second-line test to evaluate for subarachnoid hemorrhage when initial head CT is negative but clinical suspicion remains high. The presence of neck stiffness suggests meningeal irritation, and CTA can identify aneurysmal sources and vascular abnormalities. Another appropriate second-line test is lumbar puncture.

C) INCORRECT:

Observation alone is inappropriate when clinical suspicion for subarachnoid hemorrhage remains high despite negative initial CT. The presence of neck stiffness indicates meningeal irritation requiring diagnostic evaluation rather than monitoring, as delayed diagnosis of SAH can lead to catastrophic outcomes.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI brain without contrast is not the most appropriate immediate next step for suspected subarachnoid hemorrhage with meningeal signs. Other diagnostic modalities are preferred.

E) INCORRECT:

Repeating head CT would not add diagnostic value in this scenario. CT sensitivity for SAH does not significantly improve with serial imaging, and other modalities are needed to definitively rule out SAH when initial CT is negative but meningeal signs are present.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 6-hour history of severe headache. She reports having similar headaches 2–3 times per month for the past 18 months. These are typically bilateral and in the temporal region, last 8–12 hours, and usually improve with ibuprofen and rest. Today's headache began similarly but has become significantly more severe than her previous episodes. She rates it 9/10 compared to her usual 6/10. She denies fever, neck stiffness, or visual changes. Vital signs are normal, and neurological examination shows no focal deficits. Which finding classifies this as a high-risk headache requiring emergency diagnostic evaluation?

choices.text: Severity rating of 9/10 on pain scale
Significant change in headache severity pattern

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The anatomical location of headache pain does not serve as a red flag criterion for high-risk classification. Both primary and secondary headaches can manifest with bilateral temporal pain, and anatomical location without other concerning features does not indicate the need for emergency diagnostic evaluation.

B) INCORRECT:

Pain severity alone is not a reliable factor for risk stratification. Both primary headaches, such as migraine, and secondary headaches can manifest with severe pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Headache duration alone does not determine risk stratification. Both primary and secondary headaches can have variable durations, and the temporal course must be considered in context with other clinical features.

D) INCORRECT:

Age greater than 40 years is not a red flag criterion. The SNOOP10 criteria specify that age greater than 50 years at onset of a new headache pattern constitutes a red flag feature for high-risk headache.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- A change in pattern or recent onset of headache represents one of the key SNOOP10 red flag criteria. Even in patients with established headache patterns, a significant change in severity, character, or frequency elevates the presentation to high-risk status requiring further diagnostic evaluation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe, sudden-onset headache that started 2 hours ago while exercising. She describes this as the worst headache of her life. Her vital signs are normal, and physical examination shows no abnormalities. There is no history of recent trauma. What is the most appropriate initial diagnostic study?

choices.text: MRI brain with and without contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI brain without contrast is not the recommended initial imaging study for sudden-onset severe headache suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage.

B) INCORRECT:

CT head with contrast is not the recommended initial imaging study for sudden-onset severe headache suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – CT head without contrast is the recommended initial imaging modality for sudden-onset severe (thunderclap) headache. This presentation is highly suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage, and CT without contrast effectively detects acute blood in the subarachnoid space.

D) INCORRECT:

CTA head and neck is not used as an initial study for suspected SAH. It is an appropriate follow-up study if initial testing is normal but clinical suspicion remains high.

E) INCORRECT:

MRI brain with and without contrast is not the initial imaging choice for acute thunderclap headache. This study takes longer to obtain than CT and is not the preferred initial modality for detecting acute subarachnoid hemorrhage in the emergency setting.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents with a 4-hour history of headache that began during exercise at the gym. The pain is described as 8/10, bilateral, and constant. He has no fever, neck stiffness, or focal neurological deficits. Vital signs are BP, 165/95; P, 88; T, 37.0°C (98.6°F). CT head without contrast shows no acute abnormalities. After receiving IV ketorolac and being placed in a quiet, dimly lit room, his headache decreases to 5/10 and his blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg, but he continues to report nausea and difficulty tolerating oral fluids. What is the most appropriate disposition for this patient?

choices.text: Admit for IV hydration and observation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Discharge home with oral analgesics alone is not appropriate for this patient. Exercise-induced onset, age over 50 years, and inability to tolerate oral fluids are concerning features that require further evaluation and supportive care.

B) INCORRECT:

While neurology follow-up may be appropriate, discharge is not safe for this patient, who cannot tolerate oral fluids and has multiple concerning features requiring inpatient evaluation and management.

C) INCORRECT:

ED observation units are designed for patients requiring 6–24 hours of care to determine disposition, but this patient already meets clear indications for hospitalization due to intractable pain and inability to tolerate oral nutrition or hydration.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Hospital admission is appropriate for intractable pain and inability to tolerate oral nutrition or hydration.

E) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is not indicated because this patient has no signs of meningitis, no fever, and normal neurological examination. Normal CT scan within 6 hours of symptom onset makes subarachnoid hemorrhage unlikely, and there are no clinical features suggesting central nervous system infection.
